body_text.text: In Italy, a 60-million-inhabitant country divided into 20 Regions further divided into provinces, the first COVID-19 case was detected on February 21, 2020 in the large 10-,million-inhabitant Lombardy Region. Since than, more than 50,000 cases were reported in the county in the following 30 days, with more than 6000 deaths. More than 28,000 cases and 3700 deaths regarded Lombardy alone, but all the Regions were progressively hit [1] . In an attempt to stop the virus from spreading, Italy was progressively put under a lockdown.

Based on COVID -19 cases exported from Italy, Tuite et al. estimated that, as of February 29, 72% of Italian cases could be non-identified [2] . Different regions and provinces showed different approaches to face the epidemic, different aggressiveness of case finding efforts. For example, as of March 24, the 5-million-inhabitant Veneto Region, with approximately 5,500 cases detected and less than 200 deaths, collected 61,000 nasal swabs (1 every 74 inhabitants), whereas in Lombardy only 73,000 were collected (1 every 131 inhabitants) [1] .

Epidemic growth and COVID -19 incidence rates also vary across the country [3] . It is possible that, in addition to population age distribution, prevalence of chronic conditions and lifestyles, different approaches in managing outbreaks could affect the epidemic magnitude and outcomes.

In the 1.2-million-inhabitant Friuli Venezia Giulia (FVG) Region, in the North-East of Italy, the first cases were detected one week later than in Lombardy. Even within this relatively small region, there are different approaches to the disease. We describe the course and management of a cluster of COVID-19 cases in Remanzacco, a 6000-inhabitant town in Udine province of FVG.

The first case of this local outbreak had the first upper respiratory specimen collected through swab on February 29 after a contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case from another Region, during an agriculture engineering congress held in Udine on February 20-21. From this congress many attendees resulted positive to COVID-19 in various Italian cities. 3 After positivity of the first case, swabs were collected from close contacts on March 1. Between February 29 and March 16, the Prevention Department of Udine traced, collected nasal swabs, and followed all symptomatic and asymptomatic close contacts of the initial case and of any further detected case. The outbreak network is shown in supplemental Figure S1 .

Real-time RT-PCR assays for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 on upper respiratory specimens collected though swabs were conducted at the Virology and Microbiology Laboratories of Udine according to the WHO guidance [4] . The responses were available after an average of 5 hours.

Overall, 143 persons were traced and followed. Forty-eight lived in Remanzacco, the others in neighboring towns. Based on epidemiological and clinical criteria, no swabs were collected from 63 subjects, however, 54 of them were precautionary quarantined. Swabs were collected from all the other persons, who were either quarantined in case of negative test result or isolated in case of positivity. 111 people providing email addresses were sent quarantine instructions.

All quarantined persons were periodically monitored by telephone to assess clinical conditions. During follow-up, one person whose first swab was negative underwent a second collection after developing symptoms 7 days later and resulted positive.

Including this person, confirmed cases were 18. Dates of the first positive swabs are shown in Figure 1 . Median age was 46.5 years (interquartile range 42-56, range 17-73); 9 were females. Cases were clinically monitored daily by telephone for a total of 101 telephone calls. All cases but one were initially isolated at home; one was hospitalized. Eleven cases (61%) were asymptomatic at first swab collection. Their median age was 45 years (vs 47 in subjects with symptoms at first swab).

In addition to the person with first negative swab and second positive swab, other two initially asymptomatic persons with first positive swab developed symptoms (including cough in both cases) respectively after 7 and 15 days; both were hospitalized. An additional person, initially symptomatic with fever and cough, was hospitalized with bilateral pneumonia 6 days after the first positive swab. 4 As of March 20, all 18 infected people were either still asymptomatic or had clinically recovered. As of March 30, 15 (83%) were microbiologically negative (i.e., tested negative in two different consecutive occasions). All had two negative swabs by April 6 (Figure 1 ). All the other persons concluded their quarantine period. No additional cases related to any of the 18 cases of the Remanzacco cluster were reported.

This experience shows that prompt contact tracing of confirmed cases and extensive collection of nasal swabs from close, even asymptomatic, contacts of cases, with consequent isolation or quarantine, can be effective in extinguishing the COVID-19 epidemic. In our setting, synergic work of Infectious Disease Clinic, Prevention Department, and Virology and Microbiology Laboratories made these resource-consuming activities possible and effective.

In Udine province, since there were only 3 cases at end of February, we tried to identify clusters of COVID-19 in an attempt to reduce the number of infected persons and prevent massive afflux of severe cases to hospitals. Thus, we collected swabs not only from symptomatic patients but also from asymptomatic close contacts of confirmed cases. As of March 24, we collected 1 swab every 94 inhabitants in Udine province, vs 1 every 142 in the whole FVG Region.
From February 23 the FVG government decided to shutdown schools and universities, possibly contributing to the favorable outcome of this outbreak.

In conclusion, although difficult due to the high proportion of asymptomatic patients able to transmit the infection, contact tracing, identification and isolation of cases might reduce the number of infected subjects and even stop small outbreaks.

Ethics: This letter does not report the results of a research project but describes a case of public health practice, for which no ethical approval was needed.
